title: Bilateral Mixed Hearing Loss / Otosclerosis
chief_complaint: I've noticed a significant increase in difficulty hearing soft speech in my work environment, even when I'm wearing my hearing aids.

problem_summary.course: Progressive; significant worsening noticed since last exam 3 years ago.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty hearing soft speech at work despite amplification.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Wants to address the increased difficulty hearing.

history.present_illness: Patient reports a long-standing history of bilateral hearing loss and currently uses amplification. He noticed a recent decline in hearing ability, specifically for soft speech at work. Last evaluation 3 years prior showed mixed loss with smaller air-bone gaps (10-15 dB).
history.otologic_history: No reported history of ear pathology, otosurgery, or noise exposure. Denies tinnitus or dizziness.
history.medical_psych_history: Family history of hearing loss (2 of 5 siblings).
history.patient_goals: Improve hearing for soft speech in work environment.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Moderately severe hearing loss (250-3000 Hz) sloping to severe (4000-8000 Hz). Mixed component at 250-1000 Hz with air-bone gaps of 25-30 dB HL. Left ear: Moderate gradually sloping to moderately severe (250-2000 Hz) then severe (3000-8000 Hz). Mixed component at 250-1000 Hz and 4000 Hz with air-bone gaps of 20-30 dB HL.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT scores were in agreement with PTA. Word recognition scores (WRS) revealed slight difficulty in the ability to recognize speech at suprathreshold levels.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Hypocompliant (Type As). Left ear: Normal (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Absent acoustic reflex thresholds from 500 to 4,000 Hz for ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation bilaterally. Decay could not be measured.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral, asymmetric mixed hearing loss, ranging from moderate to severe. There is a significant conductive component in the low frequencies (air-bone gaps of 20â€“30 dB) superimposed on a sensorineural loss. Speech recognition remains good at elevated levels. Immittance testing shows reduced compliance in the right ear and absent reflexes bilaterally, consistent with middle ear pathology such as otosclerosis.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a 'mixed' hearing loss, meaning there is both nerve-related loss and a mechanical issue in the middle ear preventing sound from getting through efficiently.
The mechanical issue (conductive component) has progressed since your last visit 3 years ago, which explains why you are struggling more with soft speech.
Based on these results, I am referring you to an ENT specialist to evaluate for otosclerosis, a condition where the middle ear bones become stiff.
There are surgical options to correct the mechanical part of the hearing loss, or we can continue to manage this with hearing aids.
We should evaluate you for Hearing Assistive Technology (HAT) to help in your specific work environment.
notes_for_actor: You are an older gentleman (approx 80) still active in a work environment.
You are not complaining of pain or dizziness, just frustration that your hearing aids aren't working as well as they used to.
You are hesitant about surgery; if offered, you should express a preference to stick with hearing aids for now.
